articles.title: GRAND TOUR OF THE SOLAR SYSTEM
articles.summary: The document outlines a schedule of astronomical events for March and early April, primarily held at the Los Gatos Red Cross Building. Events include general meetings with specific programs like 'Grand Tour of the Solar System' by Bernie Haisch, an indoor astronomy class, board meetings, and an indoor star party. A field expedition for a Messier Marathon at Henry Coe State Park and an Astrophoto Symposium at Moorpark College are also scheduled.
keywords: Grand Tour of the Solar System

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: The article announces several key events and news for an astronomical group. It details a March 7th general meeting featuring Bernie Haisch on the solar system, reports the results of the February 7th SJAA board elections, provides instructions for the 7th Annual Bay Area Astronomical Auction, and promotes the upcoming 7th Astrophotography Conference in March, encouraging members to attend.

articles.title: DR. FREEMAN GOES TO SPACE CAMP, PART II
articles.summary: In 'DR. FREEMAN GOES TO SPACE CAMP, PART II,' Jay Freeman recounts his experience piloting a Space Shuttle simulator at the Houston Space Center. Despite his background as a lightplane pilot, he successfully guided the simulated shuttle into orbit, crediting the predictable controls and sophisticated display design. He concludes by reflecting on the differences between the simulation and a real-life ascent, acknowledging the additional challenges of actual space flight.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: Don Machholz's "Comet Comments" reports on a recent surge in comet discoveries and recoveries, highlighting the significant contributions of amateur astronomers who visually found three new comets. The article provides detailed updates on the observational status, magnitudes, and orbital characteristics of several specific comets, including Du Toit-Hartley, Levy, Wiseman-Skiff, Nishikawa-Takamizawa-Tago, Terasako, and Wild. It offers insights into their visibility for Northern Hemisphere observers and projected brightness over the coming months.

articles.title: EPHEMERIDES
articles.summary: This article provides the ephemerides for Comet Terasako (1987d) from late February to early April, detailing its right ascension, declination, elongation, and predicted magnitude. It notes the comet is rapidly dimming and moving away from Earth and the Sun, predicting it will be lost in the evening sky by late March. The data is based on a preliminary parabolic orbit, with a special note about its proximity to M27 on March 14.

articles.title: Comet Wilson (1986L)
articles.summary: Comet Wilson (1986L) will be briefly visible in the morning sky from late February through early May. Observers north of 35° N latitude are favored in early March, while those south of 35° will have better views later in the month before the comet moves too far south for mid-northern latitudes until mid-May. The article provides an ephemeris for its visibility period.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Halley (1982i)
articles.summary: This article presents an ephemeris for Periodic Comet Halley (1982i) from late February to early April, detailing its celestial coordinates, elongation, and estimated magnitude. It describes the comet's movement from Hydra to Sextans, its close encounter with galaxy 3115 on March 31, and notes that it should be observable with a 10" telescope, despite some reports of it being brighter than listed.

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: The article discusses two distinct astronomical topics: the prevalence of mistaken comet sightings and a detailed guide for the 1987 Messier Marathon. It explains that many amateur and professional comet reports are 'forgetables' caused by optical illusions, photographic flaws, or misidentified faint objects like NGC 404. The second section provides extensive information for the 1987 Messier Marathon, outlining the best dates (March 28/29) for observing the maximum number of Messier objects, historical context, optimal conditions, and suggested observing locations for participants.

articles.title: WILL BE:
articles.summary: An astronomical swap meet is scheduled for Saturday, May 2nd at 6:00 PM at the Los Gatos Red Cross, with doors opening at 2:00 PM. This event offers an opportunity to buy and sell a wide variety of astronomical equipment, including telescopes, eyepieces, camera gear, and accessories. Attendees are encouraged to bring their own items to sell and can pre-register for convenience.

articles.title: The 7th Annual Bay Area Astronomical Auction
articles.summary: The article announces the 7th Annual Bay Area Astronomical Auction, urging participants to pre-register astronomical and telescope-making related items for sale. Pre-registration via mail involves detailing items, setting minimum prices, and indicating a percentage of sale for the SJAA (a minimum of 10% or outright tax-deductible donations), with all proceeds supporting public astronomy education. Early registration ensures smoother processing, assigned numbers, and avoids delays on auction day.

articles.title: DIRECTIONS TO THE AUCTION:
articles.summary: This document provides directions to an auction held at the Los Gatos Red Cross buildings (16011 Los Gatos-Saratoga Rd). Doors open at 2 PM for registration, with item registration closing at 5:45 PM and the auction starting promptly at 6 PM. Payment can be made by cash or check, and a $1 bidder/seller registration fee applies, with a pre-registration form also provided.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA holds monthly General Meetings and "Indoor Star Parties" at the Los Gatos Red Cross building, fostering a friendly environment for diverse astronomical interests like astrophotography, deep sky observation, and telescope making. These meetings occur on the 4th Saturday of each month, with doors opening at 7:45 PM and meetings beginning at 8 PM, and detailed directions are provided for attendees.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: Monthly "Indoor Star Parties" offer informal gatherings for amateur astronomers to socialize, share interests, and discuss astronomy. Activities typically include telescope observations in the parking lot, astrophotography slide shows, and also host SJAA board meetings and introductory astronomy workshops. These events are held at the Los Gatos Red Cross Building.

articles.title: HENRY COE STATE PARK
articles.summary: This document provides detailed directions to an observing site at Henry Coe State Park, accessible via Hwy 101 south towards Morgan Hill. It includes specific instructions for navigating to the park, locating a locked gate with a club combination (4585), and important advice for locking the gate and arriving after dark. The site is used by the SJAA for equipment setup.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak State Park is highlighted as a popular astronomical observing site, frequently utilized by the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) for new moon weekend events and home to the FPOA's public observatory. The article provides detailed directions to the park and mentions the common presence of 30-40 telescopes during clear nights. Additionally, it lists the officers and board members of the SJAA, along with information about their monthly publication, EPHEMERIS.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), detailing different membership types and their associated costs, including options for 'Membership Only', 'Membership/S&T' (likely Sky & Telescope), and 'Junior' (under 18). It provides fields for applicant information and instructions for submission, either at an SJAA meeting or by mail to the treasurer.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary: This document presents an optional questionnaire designed to gauge an individual's astronomical interests (e.g., astrophotography, deep-sky observation, telescope making), telescope ownership, and areas of expertise. It also includes contact and mailing information for the 'SJAA EPHEMERIS,' a non-profit organization located in San Jose, CA, and is explicitly marked as 'NEWS MATERIAL.'
